awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a small Unmanned Aircraft System (UAS) for natural and urban ecosystem studies and risk disaster management
awd_abstract_narration:
This award permits University at Albany, SUNY, to purchase an unmanned aircraft system. Researchers led by Dr. Alexander Buyantuev will use the system to conduct a multidisciplinary study focused on monitoring fast ecological and geophysical processes and advance the understanding of environmental changes at scales of individual trees to whole landscapes. Several projects that utilize near surface remote sensing made possible by the cutting edge drone technology and ground measurements will examine effects of climate warming and local anthropogenic impacts, such as soil acidification, wind power generation, and urbanization, on vegetation growth. Gaining insight into these effects is of great importance to predict more accurately the state of ecosystems in the future and to develop sound mitigation strategies. Researchers will also be committed to look closely into the use of the technology in identifying best practices and developing protocols for post-storm area analysis and future emergency management applications. Overall, these studies are expected to benefit a large number of students and the public by either their direct involvement in the work or through exposure to research during classwork or public presentations.

Dr. Buyantuev with colleagues will use a professional grade unmanned aircraft system (UAS) outfitted with visual, multi (hyper-) spectral, thermal, and laser sensors to collect geospatial data at forested field sites and near developed areas. Such very high resolution data will provide the missing link in scaling between ground sampling and airborne and spaceborne remote sensing, primarily data from widely used Landsat and MODIS satellites. It will allow researchers to assess how climate warming and associated changes in timing of tree growth affect the dynamics of nonstructural carbon in spruce trees and understand better the effects of soil acidification and warming on growing season arrival and length for sugar maple stands in Upstate New York, USA. The team is also particularly interested in how wind turbines, being the sources of alternative and environmentally friendly power production, and the process of urbanization characterized by the expansion of built-up land, modify local climates and vegetation/crop growth. These effects will be studied by quantifying inter-annual growing seasons and biomass changes in the vicinity of an existing wind farm and along the gradient of land development in a suburban site.  The research will generate valuable datasets and methods for processing high resolution imagery into important scientific information.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided the unmanned aircraft system (UAS) to the interdisciplinary team of researchers in the University at Albany, SUNY. We purchased the Lancaster 4 platform by Precision Hawk, which consisted of a ground control station and the fixed-wing unmanned aircraft outfitted with a set of swappable imaging sensors. Until its destruction in 2018 this versatile system was used to collect data in support of research projects in several locations in Upstate New York and Costa Rica. We later obtained several rotary-wing aircrafts, or copters, and integrated our sensors for use with those newer UASs. This small fleet of UASs constitutes the Remote Sensing and Small Aircraft Systems lab in the Department of Geography and Planning of our university.

Our work has demonstrated the many ways modern day UAS can contribute to scientific advances in geography, remote sensing, ecology and other related disciplines. Our research team has produced evidence that near surface remote sensing made possible by UAS and instruments acquired as part of the award can play a pivotal role in reconciling plant phenology, defined as the study of recurring phases of vegetation development. Our project assessed phenology across scales and advanced our understanding of the relations between tree physiology dynamics, tree canopy phenology, and satellite-observed landscape phenology. We have also developed and tested a methodology for UAS-assisted wildlife surveys by combining thermal and multispectral imaging to assist in detection of while-tailed deer population and its habitat use in the Albany Pine Bush preserve near our university. In the broader context, our instrumentation has been used to map the Las Mercedes excavation site in Costa Rica, the result of our collaboration with archaeologists, and provided imagery for mapping graveyards in support of the Albany Rural Cemetery Explorer project led by our department. The goal of the project is to develop a GIS-based cell phone technology that enables visitors to tour the cemetery and obtain records of the deceased.

The project has generally enhanced scientific and technological understanding of the use of unmanned aircrafts through broad dissemination of the results and experiences. This has been facilitated by sharing our findings through publication in peer-reviewed literature and conference proceedings, discussing them at national and international conferences, and integrating the instrumentation and methods of data collection into several courses regularly taught by the project’s principal investigator. One shared-resource course, Geospatial Applications of Drones, was specifically developed to provide adequate training to both graduate an undergraduate students interested in this technology. The project provided many training and professional development opportunities to Master's, Doctoral, and undergraduate students from five different programs (Geography, Urban Studies and Planning, Biodiversity, Conservation and Planning, Geographic Information Science, and PhD in Information Science). One PhD dissertation, two Master theses, and one undergraduate thesis, as well as numerous independent study projects have been completed in our lab. Our group has become known across our university as the leading unit equipped with tools and knowledge for conducting near surface remote sensing with our drones.
